It's been a while, but here's a new movie post. Huzzah!
Amongst the things that writer/director David Cronenberg is known for are his entries into the "body horror" genre of film. Body horror is just that - the horror comes from something that goes terribly wrong with the human body (mutation, degeneration, invasion by a foreign organism, etc.) or simply the fear that something is happening to one's body. Cronenberg's films are definitely at the head of the genre; it's easy to tell that he's just at home in body horror, and he really goes all out with these things. Videodrome is a great example of this. Videodrome begins with Max Renn, the incredibly sleazy president of a local cable TV station who is eternally on the hunt for the one show that will shock and repulse enough people to secure him a decently sized audience. Max steals shows he picks up from signals originating all across the world, and he chooses only the seediest, most violent and sexually charged programming to fill his time slots. Obviously, he is a very controversial figure and even shows up on a talk show or two in order to defend the shows he chooses to put onto his network. One day, one of Max's technical staff members picks up transmissions of an insanely violent show called "Videodrome" that is nothing but people being tortured and mutilated from start to finish, with no plot to speak of. Max is, of course, completely fascinated right away, realizing that "Videodrome" could be the show that helps his fledgling network hit the big time. Despite warnings from a friend that what "Videodrome" shows is actual torture and murder ("snuff TV" as the film calls it), and that he could get in huge trouble if he airs the program, Max decides to go ahead and get in contact with the creators of the show. Once he starts watching it more, however, Max starts to get second thoughts. His girlfriend, a masochistic woman who is bizarrely intrigued by the show, goes to audition and disappears. Before she left, Max began to have hallucinations, and these only intensify when she is gone; he imagines that the Betamax tape with "Videodrome" on it is pulsating, as is his television. Max gets a gun for protection, but a hole opens up in his stomach and then swallows the gun whole. Max is understandably freaked out by this and he desperately tries to find the makers of "Videodrome," but he is subsequently sucked deeper and deeper into things beyond his command as he struggles to maintain control of his body and his slipping hold on reality. First of all, you can't talk about this film (or many of Cronenberg's other films for that matter lol) without mentioning the special effects - they're fucking nuts. Not quite as wild as what you'll find in The Fly, but not that far off either. Besides the aforementioned holes in stomachs and pulsing televisions and Betamax tapes, there's also exploding body parts aplenty, mutations, and a very violent, grisly fate met by one of the characters that I couldn't help but watch a few times in a row. Unlike a lot of other movies where the effects are there just for the sake of being there, the special effects in this film really do add a lot to the whole experience. Unless you're really disturbed by effects of that nature, you'll never find yourself without something interesting to watch in Videodrome. One thing that I think is explored effectively is our obsession with violence - hell, the fact that I watched that horrible death scene more than once is at least somewhat indictive of that obsession. Max is always on the hunt for the most violent show possible, because he believes that is the future of television. And, guess what, it gets him noticed. He's brought on to talk shows so that the hosts can condemn what he is doing, but he's still getting attention. Instead of turning people from Max's network, it more than likely draws more viewers to him. Then, when Max finally gets his hands on "Videodrome," he becomes a complete slave to it, literally and figuratively. The thing drives him nuts but he can't stop watching it and listening to its suggestions, and it drives him to do things that even he would not have done without its influence. It's too much for him to ignore. Another thing that I really like is the creepy, surreal mood of the whole thing. Obviously the visual effects go a long way towards establishing that. All of the nutty things that happen to Max and everybody else keep escalating, so there's always a feeling of, "What the hell is going on here??" The music also contributes well to the mood, though honestly it sometimes smacks way too much of the 80s lol (too much synth, etc.). I think that Max's reactions to everything also make Videodrome a bit more unnerving. At first the guy is like, "WTF?" just like anybody else would be... but eventually he grows so serious about and accepting of all of the crazy crap going on everywhere, and it's kind of unsettling. That's how it made me feel, anyway lol. There are some points where the plot becomes really ambiguous, though probably deliberately so. After a certain point it's almost impossible to tell what is actually happening in reality and what is just a part of Max's hallucinations. It makes the story a bit confusing, but it works to show deep "Videodrome" has gotten into Max. It's pretty clear that the guy ceases to be himself the moment he enters the world of "Videodrome." The more into its world he becomes, the less he's able to actually control his own mind and the more prone he is to manipulation from others, especially those who are pulling "Videodrome"'s strings. I'm sure that during the latter half of the film the guy barely knows where he is or what he's even doing, and the story sort of follows that line as well, not really stopping to answer questions to a certain degree. It works for me, but if you don't like ambiguity, then it probably won't work for you lol. If you're into horror, then you should definitely give Videodrome a watch. It's a smart, creepy, violent film with fantastic special effects: What more could you ask for, really?

This is one of the few times that you're likely to see a movie rant on here, mostly because I'd rather stick to posting about, you know, good movies, but I feel that this movie needs to be mocked and mocked well. I was going to do a rant after watching The Boondock Saints, too, though I guess I'll be shelving that one for another time. This one is more urgent.
Maybe the most frustrating thing about this film is that it actually does a lot of things right: It's visually stylish and sets a cool mood, the actors do a reasonably good job, and there are some good scenes here and there. But where Oldboy starts going wrong is after the first fifteen or so minutes when the story starts to really get going. After that, the movie's plot becomes almost too absurd for words and climaxes with what is possibly one of the flimsiest explanations for any evil scheme in the world ever. That's not hyperbole, by the way, as you shall soon see. Normally I try to avoid giving away spoilers, because I hate it when I have things spoiled for me beforehand, but I hope that you all will forgive me for deeming the spoilers necessary for mocking this pile of crap as much as possible. The story begins with a Korean businessman, Oh Dae-su, who has been picked up by the police for being drunk and is hanging around the police station, bothering people. A friend comes to bail him out, and Dae-su leaves with him after first insulting the police. (Ladies and gentlemen: Your hero!!) Then, Dae-su's friend calls Dae-su's wife and tells her that he's bringing her husband home as soon as possible and that Dae-su has a present for his daugther's birthday (a pair of wings). While Dae-su's friend turns his back, however, Dae-su suddenly disappears. I hope for a minute that he's disappeared from the film, but alas, it is not meant to be. In the next scene, we see Dae-su peeking out from under an opening for food; for the past couple of months, Dae-su has been held captive in some sort of cheap hotel room, his only contact with the outside world coming from the television. Whenever his captors need to come into the room to do something, or when Dae-su is being unruly, gas is released into the room to knock him out. If only we could be so lucky. Anyway, it is by watching the news that Dae-su learns that his wife has been murdered, his daughter placed under foster care, and that he has been charged with the crime. Naturally, this just about causes the poor guy to go mad and he spends the next fifteen years filling notebooks with details on all of the shitty things he's done in his life in order to figure out who would hate him enough to imprison him, using a metal chopstick he yoinked to dig a hole through the wall after his captors accidentally gave him an extra chopstick, and he also trains by shadow boxing and punching the wall of the room he's in until thick calluses form on his knuckles. It's like I always say: The best training in the world can only be found by being locked up in a shithole for fifteen years. After fifteen years (the same fifteen years, not an extra fifteen years), Dae-su finally makes a decent sized hole in the wall but then finds that he is on the roof of a building, and that escape would be impossible. However, Dae-su then wakes up abruptly on the roof of a different building dressed in a suit with a wallet full of money, a cellphone, and his prison journals. While he's adjusting to the light (I imagine the effect is just like walking out of the theater after watching The Lord of the Rings: Return of the King), Dae-su sees a man standing on the roof of the building with his dog. Dae-su tries to speak to him, but because it's been so long since he last talked to a person, Dae-su has no idea how to react. Neither do I, really, but hey! We then learn that the guy is suicidal, and he says to Dae-su, "Even though I'm no more than a beast, don't I have the right to live?" He then follows this up by attempting to kill himself. He then suggests to Dae-su that they go upstairs and talk, which of course means that Dae-su is attacked by a couple of thugs as soon as he exits the elevator. After he dispatches them with relative ease, Woo-jin's bodyguard is finally like, "Okay, we'll talk. Damn." In the next scene, Woo-jin is walking around naked for some reason, and Dae-su reiterates all that he has learned, and further insinuates that Woo-jin killed his sister and made it seem like a suicide. His evidence?? A picture of Soo-ah just before her death with the date of her death marked on it OMG!!!!! Woo-jin smirks and brushes off the charge. Dae-su also whines a bit because he believes that Woo-jin hypnotized him in order to make him forget what happened. Woo-jin also brushes that wack shit off, too, and tells Dae-su that he forgot only because it wasn't important to him. But then Woo-jin does admit to having someone hypnotize Dae-su and goes on a rambling speech about post-hypnotic suggestion. And then he reveals his grand scheme to the eventual horror of Dae-su (get good and ready for this contrived, bizarre nonsense): Woo-jin had both Dae-su and Mi-do hypnotized, and planted suggestions in Dae-su's head that would lead him to the sushi bar where Mi-do worked. His next reaction was to be after the cellphone rang, where he would pick it up and immediately ask, "Who are you?" Mi-do was instructed to react to the man who said this and then to grab his hand. Dae-su's reaction to this would be to faint, whereupon Mi-do would take him home. Woo-jin's hope was that Dae-su and Mi-do would fall in love, which is exactly what happened. Woo-jin then says that Dae-su had been asking the wrong questions the entire time: He should've been asking "Why did Woo-jin release me after fifteen years?" rather than "Why did Woo-jin imprison me?" Dae-su obviously still hasn't figured things out, and though Woo-jin is of course enjoying this, he leads Dae-su's gaze to another purple present that is lying on his desk. Dae-su opens the present. He finds a photo album inside. As he flips through the photo album, it slowly dawns on him what Woo-jin's horrible, evil, disgusting, and just-plain-wrong plan was the entire time... Yep, Mi-do is Dae-su's God damn DAUGHTER and good ol' Woo-jin got them to have incest as well. Dae-su is understandably horrified (as was I by this point, though more by the fact that somebody thought that this made for a good movie), and Woo-jin is standing around with a big shit-eaing grin on his face that just screams, "HAHA @ U I MADE U FUCK UR DAUGHTER SCORE!!" Woo-jin then informs Dae-su that there is a present over where Mi-do is, too (of course Park had been working for Woo-jin the whole time - he traded his hand for a house), and Dae-su begs Woo-jin not to tell Mi-do, even going so far as to cut off his tongue so that he'll never talk too much again. Since he has already gotten his revenge on Dae-su, and he really has no more reason to live (I could've told him that a long time ago), Woo-jin takes pity on Dae-su and decides not to tell. He then leaves Dae-su to listen to a tape that he made of Dae-su and Mi-do's vigorous lovemaking session. (I hope that's all Woo-jin used it for, by the way.) (EDIT: Something else I forgot to mention here - according to Woo-jin, after he had Dae-su's wife killed, he then secretly raised Dae-su's daughter. How does Mi-do not recognize him?? More hypnosis, I guess. How terribly convenient.) While riding down the elevator, Woo-jin has a flashback to the day Soo-ah died, shit happens, she's at peace, he's crying like a baby, she dies, and I don't even care anymore. GOD JUST END ALREADY. Woo-jin then obliges me by blowing his brains out after the elevator stops at the bottom of the building. The film then inexplicably shifts to a snowy landscape where we see Dae-su crawling around, miserable. He eventually finds the hypnotist who originally hypnotized he and Mi-do, and he begs her to help him forget all that had happened to him. She says that she originally was not going to help him, until she read the last sentence of a letter he had sent her: "Even though I'm no more than a beast, don't I have the right to live?" She says that she was touched by this (and not in the Woo-jin/Soo-ah sense of the phrase), and she agrees to relieve Dae-su of his horrible memory. To do this, she uses hypnosis to split Dae-su into two personalities: A beast who remembers all this incestual nonsense, and regular old Dae-su who does not. The hypnotist says that the beast will age one year for every step that he takes; after seventy years, he will die. Dae-su then awaks in the snow, and of all people, Mi-do is there. Mi-do hugs him, telling him that she loves him, while Dae-su at first has a smile which slowly turns into a scowl. Did he really get hypnotized?? Does he still remember his night of glorious fucking with his daughter?? Are we really supposed to give two shits about any of this?? And that's the end of Oldboy. Jesus, what a freaking awful movie. Ed Wood would have given his left testicle to come up with a story like that. Obviously Dae-su is supposed to be some sort of Oedipus-like tragic figure, but the whole plot is so random, far-fetched and rigoddamndiculous that the only tragic thing about the film is that it's tragically hilarious. I mean, when I start thinking that a plot is ridiculous to the point of insanity, then something must be seriously wrong, because I'll readily admit to have enjoyed some incredibly bizarre plots in my time. This is just way beyond that, though. In closing, I think that this is appropriate: Oh Dae-su? More like Oh Dae-SUCK HAHA DO YOU SEE WHAT I DID THERE Thank you and good night.

Slow goings here lately (as evidenced by the lack of updates), but here's a movie post for you guys! I think that every movie post I've done so far has been about a comedy... lol.
Clue is living proof that not all films based upon board games are bad, though this is the only film adaptation of a board game that I know of (I'm still holding out hope for Hi Ho! Cherry-O, however). You wouldn't think that anything having to do with a board game would make for a good movie, but seeing as Clue is a board game about solving murders, it can be assumed that there is no way that anybody could screw that up. And it just so happens that it wasn't screwed up! There would have been murders-a-plenty had that not been the case... The film begins with the butler, Wadsworth, making the final preparations before receiving guests for the evening. The guests are of course the characters from the board game, and Col. Mustard is the first to arrive, followed by Mrs. White, Mrs. Peacock, Mr. Green, and Prof. Plum and Miss Scarlet, who arrive together after happening upon each other on the road. Each guest is immediately suspicious of the circumstances, as not only did they all get the same anonymous invitation, but it's also quite obvious that some of the guests know not only each other but some of the workers in the mansion as well. Before things can get too interesting, however, Wadsworth scoots everyone off to dinner. After some initial hesitation, the guests begin chatting with each other and even divulge some personal information, even though the whole purpose of using pseudonyms is to keep their identities secret. Eventually the guests figure out that they are all connected to the government in some way, and Col. Mustard gets pissed off and demands that Wadsworth tell them just why the hell they're doing at the mansion. Just then, though, the doorbell rings, Wadsworth answers it, and in saunters Mr. Boddy, the owner of the mansion; the letters that each guest received all concerned their "long-standing and painful financial [liabilities]" with Mr. Boddy, and now that he is there, they can get down to business. Everyone adjourns to the Study, though Mr. Boddy wusses out and tries to escape the mansion, only to find that there are vicious dogs guarding the exits. After he walks sullenly back into the room, Wadsworth finally reveals why they are all at the mansion: The guests have all been blackmailed for a long period of time, and Wadsworth reveals what they are all being blackmailed for so that there won't be any secrets amongst the group. One by one, in a funny sequence, Wadsworth airs their dirty laundry for all to know and see, until he at last gets to Mr. Boddy. What is Boddy's secret? He's the one who's been blackmailing them the entire time, of course! The guests are understandably pissed off at this revelation, and they all try to get a piece of Mr. Boddy. However, after he's had enough of being roughed up by everyone, Boddy tries to cut a deal with everyone: If one of them kills Wadsworth, then he won't tell the police about their illegal shenanigans; since Wadsworth has the key to the front door, they can just pack up and leave when they're done with him. If nobody kills Wadsworth, however, then Mr. Boddy swears that he will inform a shitload of newspapers about what they've all been up to, and he guarantees that they'll be all over the front pages. Boddy then opens up his case and passes out weapons to everyone to use on Wadsworth (rope, candlestick, revolver, knife, wrench, and lead pipe). He turns the lights off, someone gasps, a shot rings out, and when the lights come back on, Boddy is dead. So begins a string of murder and mayhem that'll end up very badly for a lot of people. One thing I really like about the movie is that it has a lot of energy. I imagine that most the actors (especially Tim Curry lol) were dead tired a lot of the time while the filming was going on; there's just so much going on in many of the scenes, especially after the murders get started and everybody is frantic and on edge. People are often running around from room to room, tripping and falling down, being hit on the head by falling objects, attacking each other, flailing around in fright, and more. This is a fantastic movie to watch if you're a fan of great physical comedy. The high energy of the actors also translates to the jokes, as well: Most of the puns are done in a rapid-fire style, which I think is the best way to tell the types of jokes you'll hear in Clue. They sneak up on you better if they're told quickly, and they're much funnier when you only have a split-second to think about them. I guess that there's always the danger that people will find the jokes corny, but I think that they stand up well (then again, I love puns to death, even lousy ones). Here's a particularly amusing example from the movie: Mrs. White: [My husband] didn't actually seem to like me very much; he had threatened to kill me in public. Miss Scarlet: Why would he want to kill you in public? Wadsworth: I think she meant he threatened, in public, to kill her. Miss Scarlet: Oh. Come on, grammar jokes are funny! I think that taking a grammar class has helped me appreciate that joke (and similar jokes) all the more. XD Perhaps the most interesting part of the movie is that it has multiple endings (three, in fact, though a fourth was supposedly filmed and then cut because it was thought to be too much of a downer). Upon the film's initial release, different theaters would play different versions of the movie, and you would have to go to three different theaters to see every version of the film. It's a cool concept, I think, but ultimately it was way too cumbersome and Clue didn't end up making much money in the theater. However, the movie became a cult hit when it was released on VHS, and all three endings are included on the VHS and DVDs of the film, thankfully (it would have been such bullshit if you would have had to buy three different versions of it on tape/DVD to get all of the endings lol). The endings are all pretty good (with the second one being my least favorite), though they probably create more plot holes than they resolve, haha. As for the mystery itself, well, it's okay. Not exactly Sherlock Holmes-level stuff here, but it's entertaining enough and it's not as if the mystery has to carry the movie, anyway; the comedy does a great job of that on its own, and the mystery is mostly there to provide a scenario for the jokes. The mystery is basically constructed to remain open enough to allow for the three endings, so it's kind of difficult to sort through everything and actually solve the mystery for yourself. For me, the fun in the movie is much more in the jokes and characters than solving the mystery, anyway. If you haven't seen Clue, then you should definitely give it a watch. It's on TV a lot, so there are plenty of opportunities to see it.

The Marx Brothers were one of the best (if not the best) comedy teams in history, and Duck Soup is arguably their greatest film. I've not seen every Marx Brothers film, unfortunately, but I have seen all of those that people generally count among the best of their work, and I would say that Duck Soup is definitely my favorite Marx Brothers movie (with Animal Crackers in a close second). Duck Soup begins with the nation of Freedonia on the verge of economic collapse; its people are becoming restless, and a revolution is almost assured. However, Mrs. Teasdale (Margaret Dumont), a wealthy dowager, offers $20 million to support Freedonia's government on the condition that a new leader is appointed to Freedonia. Enter Rufus T. Firefly (Groucho Marx), the newly appointed dictator of Freedonia, who flirts like mad with Mrs. Teasdale when he learns that she is a widow with piles of money (mind, he does this right after insulting her for about five minutes straight). Trentino, the ambassador of the neighboring Sylvania, doesn't take too kindly to this; he had been planning to woo Mrs. Teasdale and marry her in order to get his hands on her inherited fortune. In response to this, Trentino hires a seductive Latin dancer, Vera Marcal, to distract Firefly enough to allow Trentino to make the moves on Mrs. Teasdale. Trentino also hires two spies, Chicolini (Chico Marx) and Pinkie (Harpo Marx), to disgrace Firefly's administration and to discredit him with the people. Predictably, Chicolini and Pinkie bungle the job, switch back and forth between alliances with Trentino and Firefly, and somehow have enough time left over to harass a lemonade salesman. In the meantime, the already fragile relationship between Trentino and Firefly deteriorates to the point where the two declare war over Mrs. Teasdale. And, so, the battle between Freedonia and Sylvania rages on, and to the victor goes the spoils. Merely describing the plot of Duck Soup does not do it justice at all - the plot is relatively bare, yet there's so much going on in the movie. Duck Soup is packed with great one-liners, classic comedy sequences, hilarious songs, and sharp satire; so sharp, in fact, that Mussolini banned the film in Italy because of it. Duck Soup was the last film that the Marx Brothers did with Paramount, so they went as far as they possibly could with the unique style of humor that personified their Paramount films (as opposed to the movies they did with MGM, which mixed humor with romantic plots, non-comedic musical numbers, and clearer villains; personally, I prefer their Paramount movies by far, because they're much funnier). Everything that made the Marx Brothers great is played to the hilt in Duck Soup. For example, there are lot more songs in the Marx Brothers' films post-Duck Soup, but none of them ever got anywhere near as funny as "Just Wait 'Til I Get Through With It," where Firefly basically lays out his plans to be a repressive dictator, to abuse his power at every opportunity, and to send Freedonia into complete ruin. The song is absolutely hilarious, especially since it's sung in such an upbeat, happy tone. Evidently, Firefly could not be more pleased to have the opportunity to screw with Freedonia. Here are the lyrics to the song, for your enjoyment: These are the laws of my administration No one's allowed to smoke Or tell a dirty joke And whistling is forbidden... If chewing gum is chewed The chewer is pursued. And in the hoosegow hidden... If any form of pleasure is exhibited Report to me and it will be prohibited. I'll put my foot down, so shall it be. This is the land of the free. The last man nearly ruined this place He didn't know what to do with it If you think this country's bad off now Just wait 'til I get through with it The country's taxes must be fixed And I know what to do with it If you think you're paying too much now Just wait 'til I get through with it... I will not stand for anything that's crooked or unfair I'm strictly on the up and up So everyone beware If anyone's caught taking graft And I don't get my share We stand 'em up against the wall And pop goes the weasel. If any man should come between her husband and his bride We find out which one she prefers By letting her decide If she prefers the other man The husband steps outside We stand 'em up against the wall And pop goes the weasel. What a guy, eh? Another classic (and completely nonsensical in the grand scheme of things) sequence involves Chico and Harpo pissing off a lemonade salesman for no real reason than the fact that they can. Chico and Harpo fight each other, then demonstrate the fight for the lemonade salesman by kicking him and cutting his pockets, and then Chico and Harpo keep switching hats with the salesman for a while. Reading it makes it sound only slightly amusing, but trust me, it's very, very funny when you actually see it in the movie. Seeing people become completely exasperated always cracks me up... that's probably why I love Kif so much in Futurama. It's just fun to make certain people become very angry. :) Way later (and here's where I start going out of order lol) there's another short bit that always cracks me up: Firefly and Trentino are at each others' throats and ready to declare war, but Mrs. Teasdale has been working steadily to negotiate peace between the two. She finally convinces Trentino to speak with Firfely, and then she informs Firefly of this. He seems to be open to the possibility of peace, and thinks out loud to himself about it while Mrs. Teasdale goes to greet Trentino: Firefly: I'd be unworthy of the high trust that's been placed in me if I didn't do everything in my power to keep our beloved Freedonia in peace with the world. I'd be only too happy to meet with Ambassador Trentino, and offer him on behalf of my country the right hand of good fellowship. And I feel sure he will accept this gesture in the spirit of which it is offered. But suppose he doesn't. A fine thing that'll be. I hold out my hand and he refuses to accept! That'll add a lot to my prestige, won't it? Me, the head of a country, snubbed by a forgein ambassador! Who does he think he is, that he can come here, and make a sap of me in front of all my people? Think of it - I hold out my hand and that hyena refuses to accept! Why, the cheap ball-pushing swine, he'll never get away with it I tell you, he'll never get away with it! *Trentino enters and approaches Firefly* Firefly: So, you refuse to shake hands with me, eh? *slaps Trentino with glove* So begins the war between Freedonia and Sylvania - that scene always gets me, haha. And of course it's not possible to discuss Duck Soup without mentioning the greatness that is the mirror sequence. The set-up is simple: Pinkie and Chicolini have invaded Firefly's quarters in order to steal his war plans. While there the pair trap Firefly in his bathroom, dress up like Firefly (greaseprint mustache and all), and Pinkie procures the safe combination after a scene involving a few cases of mistaken identity. Pinkie sets off a rather loud alarm and panics; he ends up running into a mirror, breaking it into pieces. Firefly approaches the area where the mirror used to be and sees his "reflection" - Firefly then pulls out every stop to out Pinkie, but Pinkie is able to (mostly) follow Firefly's every movie. The jig is up eventually as Chicolini enters behind Pinkie after Pinkie and Firefly have finished circling each other and Firefly has given back the top hat that Pinkie had dropped onto the ground. The mirror scene is probably the most famous scene from Duck Soup. There are more great scenes (including a hilarious courtroom scene and the actual war between Freedonia and Sylvania, in which Firefly utters a line that pissed off a ton of people at the time: "You're a brave man. Go and break through the lines. And remember while you're out there risking life and limb through shot and shell, we'll be in here thinking what a sucker you are."), but I don't want to give away everything for people who haven't seen the film yet lol. Rest assured that Duck Soup (along with the rest of the Marx Brothers films!) is well worth watching. It's definitely one of the funniest movies of all time, for me. Just one more thing before I end this post: I've written a lot about how great the Marx Brothers were (and they were very great), but I have to dole out some love for Mrs. Teasdale herself, Margaret Dumont. She was an amazing straight woman, the absolute perfect comic foil for Groucho Marx. Her reactions were always golden, whether she was glowing with pleasure at Groucho's shameless flirting or in a huff at one of the many insults Groucho threw her way. I'm delighted (yes, delighted) every time she shows up in a Marx Brothers film, because it means that there's going to be more hilarious interaction between her and Groucho; frankly, I could watch the two of them play off of each other all day and I wouldn't be bored at all. They were an awesome team. Anyway, once again, watch Duck Soup: You'll be better off for it. And if you've already seen it, well, watch it again, damn it!! I'll be posting these random movie entries here for the benefit of Pyrophobic. I figure that you might be interested in reading them. :P Anyway, on to the post. :D I like to browse around IMDb every so often. I rate movies, too, mostly for the hell of it and because it's the most convenient way to keep track of what I've watched. Usually I don't take much stock in IMDb ratings; simply being on the Internet basically skews the ratings to a certain demographic. Even so, however, sometimes I can't help but see a certain rating and think to myself, "Man, why is [insert movie title here]'s rating so low? That's a good movie." Then I run away from the computer and cry myself to sleep. ...okay, not really. Anyway, I was randomly hopping about, and I happened to stop by the page for Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure. I like the movie, and IMDb's users apparently do as well... a 6.6 is a pretty solid score for IMDb. Then I went over to Bill and Ted's Bogus Journey, and was saddened to see the less than stellar score. In the words of Ted: "That was non-non-heinous." Sure, sequels aren't as good as the originals much of the time, but Bill and Ted's Bogus Journey is one of the rare exceptions to that rule in my opinion. I'd say it's about the same quality as the original... maybe a bit lower (or even higher) depending on who you talk to. So, I'll be going to bat for Bill and Ted right now. Enjoy, all fans of Bill and Ted (including John!!).
The film starts out innocuously enough: Rufus, the time traveler who helped out Bill and Ted oh so much in the first movie, is teaching a class in the utopian society that was the end result of the success of Bill and Ted's heavy metal band, Wyld Stallyns. However, there is one man who is not happy (there's always one guy who isn't happy)... namely, Chuck De Nomolos, who despises the utopian society. He takes the opportunity to seize the time-traveling phonebooth stationed in the middle of the room, and sends evil robot versions of Bill and Ted to kill the real Bill and Ted and sabotage their appearance at The Battle of the Bands. Meanwhile, in the present, Bill and Ted are busy rehearsing with (and proposing to) the two princesses they ended up with at the end of their excellent adventure. Life couldn't be better for the two, but they soon come crashing down from their high. Bill and Ted get a visit from their evil alter-egos, who trick them into thinking that the two princesses want to quit the band (Bill and Ted believe the robots, because they think that the robots are actually their future selves coming to give them advice). Then, Evil Bill and Evil Ted drive Bill and Ted out to the desert, where they reveal their nefarious plan, march Bill and Ted up to a cliff, and shove them off. Bill and Ted die and are greeted by the Grim Reaper, who tells them that if they want to stop "the evil usses," then they must defeat Death in a game for their lives. Bill and Ted give Death a melvin and run away, so that they can think up another way to bring themselves back to life. How could you not love a setup like that?? It's an incredibly silly premise, no doubt, but damned if it doesn't make for a fun, hilarious movie. Really, both Bill and Ted movies are actually well-written comedies. Yes, behind all of the 'dudes' and the 'usses' there are some very funny ideas and great lines and scenes (Death contemplating whether to exchange his traditional scythe for a gardening hoe is always good for a laugh). Speaking of Death... he's pretty damn funny in this movie. The scene where Bill and Ted finally challenge Death to a game is hilarious. It starts out ultra-serious, and then... Battleship lol. "I totally knew he would put it in the J's, dude!" Then there's Clue, electric football, and, finally, Twister. Such an awesome sequence. Besides that, a lot of the best Grim Reaper moments come from how exasperated Death is with Bill and Ted. (Like when Bill and Ted are trying to sneak into Heaven, and they make Death wear a dress after they mug a few other spirits.) They really give him a hard time... lol. For those of you who watch Futurama, Death is like the Kif to Bill and Ted's Zapp Brannigan (except that Bill and Ted aren't constantly horny like good ol' Zapp). And even though they're incredibly silly, I love the musician puns and general music-related humor in the Bill and Ted movies. It's not hard to predict that a reference to "Don't Fear the Reaper" is going to pop up somewhere, but it's still funny because Bill and Ted are so enthusiastic about it lol. (Like the great Iron Maiden joke from the first Bill and Ted film, haha.) I also enjoyed how disappointed Bill and Ted were when they first came to Hell and they found that it was not at all how album covers had depicted it. That's just the sort of weird observation you'd expect guys like Bill and Ted to make lol. The only thing that I would say brings down the movie is how dated it feels... the slang, the clothing, and the music all just scream 80s lol. The humor has aged fairly well, though. Bill and Ted's Bogus Journey isn't exactly the funniest movie in history, but I think that it would surprise some people with how genuinely sharp and funny it is. Give it a shot if you haven't seen it - the movie's lowbrow for sure, but it's the funny kind of lowbrow. :)
